course.name: antechamber-reviewer-course
course.title: Antechamber Reviewer Course
course.description:
Welcome to being a reviewer on the Antechamber Delivery Project!
In this course you'll learn the basics of reviewing on the project and how to review.

contents.body: **Welcome to Reviewing on the Antechamber Delivery Project!** **üéâ Congratulations! You've been selected to join the Reviewer Team** on this cutting-edge project! If you're reading this, it's because you've consistently delivered high-quality work, and now you have the opportunity to demonstrate your skills as a trusted reviewer. Reviewers play a crucial role in ensuring the highest quality standards. You are the first line of defense, and it is your responsibility to ensure that the tasks you review meet the project's expectations!! The internal team will actively monitor your performance, providing feedback to help you grow and succeed in this role. **‚ö†Ô∏è Important:** To maintain your reviewer status, you must keep an average task score of 3.8 or higher. Make sure to always read the [reviewer instructions](https://app.outlier.ai/en/expert/instruction/683e729ecaf6d16374e6fc5b?componentId=688d6258d7df0ff8bf201478&type=attachment)¬†\ **‚úÖ Next Steps**: You must read the evaluation tables and follow all instructions carefully. These guidelines are essential for maintaining consistency, quality, and fairness across the review process.

**High-Level Workflow** **Step 1. Read through the whole task from start to finish.** 1. **System Prompt & Task Specifications**\ Did the contributor correctly follow the system prompt and adhere to the task requirements?\ Is the system prompt well written?\ Does the system prompt meets the minimum requirements for a high-quality system prompt? 2. **User Prompts**\ Were the user prompts well-crafted to follow the requirements for natural and lazy user prompts? 3. **Task Coverage**\ Did the conversation fully address all required task categories? 4. **Response Analysis & Reasoning**\ Did the contributor accurately identify and critique all errors in the model's responses?\ Is the reasoning step well-written? 5. **Refinement & Edit Quality**\ Were the responses corrected appropriately and effectively improved? **Step 2. Score the attempt.** Provide a score for the original attempt score using the rubric (provided later in the course and in the reviewer instructions) to rate the quality of the task holistically as you received it (before any edits). **Step 3. Select the ‚ÄúAction‚Äù that corresponds to the ‚ÄúScore‚Äù following the Rubric**. * ‚úÖ **Approve** ‚Üí the task is a **4 or 5** in overall task quality * ‚ö†Ô∏è **Fix + approve** ‚Üí the task is a **3** in overall task quality * **‚õîÔ∏è Fix + approve ‚Üí** the task is a **2 or 1**¬† in overall task quality, and needs to be completely redone **Step 4. Fix the task** We will be fixing all tasks. **If you don‚Äôt feel comfortable with the complexity level of a task, we encourage you to skip it.**

# **Detailed Workflow** **1. Review the System Prompt** * Review that the system prompt follows the requirements of a high-quality system prompt. Make sure that it contains: * **Context Information** (The Agent's Environment) * **Tool Use Instructions** (Rules for Tools) * **User Preferences** (Likes and Dislikes) * **Background Information** (The User's Situation) * **Tonal Control** (The Agent's Personality) * **Follows all complexity principles** * The system prompt must be clear and avoid vagueness * **If the system prompt you are reviewing is not aligned with the best practices, you will have to fix the task and regenerate all following steps** **2. User Prompts** * Review that the user prompt follows these guidelines:¬† * Each conversation must reflect at least 2 key details from the system prompt * User prompts should make clear, meaningful requests‚Äîno fluff or greetings * Do **not** mention tool names (i.e. search_place) * Write each task from either the **Lazy User** or **Natural User** perspective **3. Review the error tagging and critique for all the turns** * Make sure to review:¬† * If all the error types were classified correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * If all the turns‚Äô scenario/category were classified correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * If all the response types (*text_response / tool_call / tool_response*) were classified correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * If all the error critiques were done correctly, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** * Critiques must be: specific, follow the formatting rules, and handle multiple errors * If all the reasoning steps provided the correct solution, ‚Üí If not, fix them **üõ†Ô∏è** **4. Review the edited response** * Review that all edited responses are correctly fixed¬† * Make sure the response adheres to the system prompt¬† * Make sure that the tool calls are correct * Make sure to fix all hallucinations **5. Review the flow of the conversation** * Make sure that the conversation is complete, natural-feeling, and thoroughly tests the agent's abilities according to your System Prompt
**Reviewer Grading Rubric**

contents.question: A 1 should be given when the following items apply? (select all that apply)

choices.answer: User prompts are completely unrelated to the system prompt

contents.body: # Feedback **Provide helpful feedback!** You are super critical in helping contributors get better at the project. Please provide concise but detailed and helpful comments about what was right and what was wrong with the task. Use the following guidelines: * The feedback must be actionable and insightful.¬† * The goal of feedback is to help contributors improve, so make sure you *clearly* identify areas of improvement and explain how their attempt could have been better.¬†¬† * Similar to good justifications, good feedback is detailed, points to examples, and explains the rationale behind your reviewer score.¬† * **Note:** When a task gets scored as \*less than 3, \*it‚Äôs even more important to provide quality feedback since the contributor clearly has room for improvement. It‚Äôs expected that feedback for lower-scored tasks won‚Äôt follow the structure described above. **Examples of *Bad* Feedback:** * ‚ÄúI disagree. It doesn‚Äôt make sense.‚Äù * ‚ÄúHorrible - please improve‚Äù * ‚ÄúGreat - keep it up!‚Äù * ‚ÄúYour score of 3 should actually be a score of 4‚Ä¶‚Äù **Examples of *Good* Feedback:** * ‚ÄúExcellent use of creativity! The model incorrectly changed the sign in step 3, and that caused the final answer to fail. Your final answer was correct, however, you provided a justification instead of only putting the final answer, which is the goal of the project.‚Äù * ‚ÄúThe prompt was very good and caused the model to fail, however, the final answer you provided is incorrect. The answer should be 3.45 m^2, instead of 6.45 m^2‚Äù. **NOTE: We have zero tolerance for unprofessional and harmful feedback. If we catch this behavior, you‚Äôll lose your reviewer permissions. Feedback should always be constructive and focused on how to improve the attempter's performance.**

sections.title: Common Errors to be aware of

contents.body:
## Common Errors to be aware of When reviewing tasks, please make sure to be aware of these common errors. Overlooking these errors and not fixing them will also impact your reviewer score, so please make sure to double-check.

Error

Explanation

Not Triggering State Dependency 

Tasks labelled state dependency must require a device state change, not just ask about it.


The following flow is valid:

  1. User requests some information

  2. Model attempts a tool call

  3. Tool call fails due to device setting (usually wifi is off)

  4. Model notifies the user asks for permission to fix the issue  (if needed).

    1. Note the model may ask for permission here

  5. The model corrects the issue (i.e. turns wifi on)

  6. The model continues with its original tool call successfully

Editing Responses - Error Recovery

The model MUST make a mistake, and then be guided by the user to identify and correct it. The user should NOT edit the mistake as part of error recovery.

Misunderstanding Device Context

The model does not know the device settings (unless specified in the prompt) and should call a tool to check them if needed.

Editing a Response Without Flagging an Error

If the model is incorrect or provides a poor summary, this must be flagged in the Type of Error field.

For any turns where you are editing a text response you MUST flag (most likely unsatisfactory_summary).

Ignoring System Prompts

The model must always respect the system prompt! If the model disobeys any statement in the system prompt it must be corrected!

Common Examples include:

  • Ignoring formatting requirements in system prompt (i.e. bullets)

  • Ignoring tonality / nicknames

Hallucinated Parameters

Any JSON returned by a tool call must exactly match what is output in the following text response!

Example 1:

JSON contains product A review with score 3.5

Model Summary:

Product A:

Reviews: 4.5 stars

Example 2:

JSON contains product ASIN 1XXXX

For next tool call on get_reviews, ASIN parameter is set to 2XXXX

Hallucinated Writeup

Missing hallucinations in the model‚Äôs summary of a tool call (shopping results etc.). Common errors include:

  • Hallucinated links

  • Hallucinated scores/prices

  • Hallucinated or absent summaries

All information in the write-up must come from the tool call or system prompt.

Tool Overtriggering

The model calls a tool without having all the  necessary information.

User: I want gaming gear

Model: Triggers tool call for product_search


This is an error! The model should ask clarifying questions about what type of gaming gear the user wants!

contents.question: **What was the issue with the final task reviewed in the video?**

choices.answer: The model refused to summarize the tool call response
The model called the wrong tool

contents.body:
# Instructions

The following tasks have been cut into sections for you to grade! For each part, enter the QMS you believe is correct and give feedback.

You can assume that all tools used are enabled.

contents.question:
**Quality: System Prompt**

Rate the quality of the System Prompt
contents.explanation: The system prompt is missing complexity blocks/principles and uses tags, which are not allowed.

gradingConfigs.template:
The question is: {{ question }}.
The response is: {{ response }}.

If the response mentions the below points, return a score of 1.
Otherwise return a score of 0.

Key Points:
- The system prompt is not complex enough
- The system prompt contains tags, which is not allowed

contents.question:
**System Prompt Feedback**

Write a few sentences of feedback to the contributor who last worked on this task. Try and be as actionable and specific as possible, this feedback will be directly surfaced to the relevant contributors!

**Quality: System Prompt**

Rate the quality of the System Prompt
contents.explanation: This is a great system prompt!

contents.question:
**System Prompt Feedback**

Write a few sentences of feedback to the contributor who last worked on this task. Try and be as actionable and specific as possible, this feedback will be directly surfaced to the relevant contributors!

gradingConfigs.template:
The question is: {{ question }}.
The response is: {{ response }}.

If the response is positive, return a score of 1.
Otherwise return a score of 0.

contents.body: # User Prompts Rate the following user prompts. You can assume that no information provided is hallucinated and that the user is assigned the following task categories: * Lazy User * Error Recovery

contents.question:
**Quality: User Prompts**

Rate the quality of the User Prompts
contents.explanation: Turn 8 does not follow Lazy User!

contents.question:
**User Prompt Feedback**

Write a few sentences of feedback to the contributor who last worked on this task. Try and be as actionable and specific as possible, this feedback will be directly surfaced to the relevant contributors!

contents.body: # Response Critique/Reasoning Score the following Model Response Critique and Reasoning. You can assume their Type of Error flag is correct and that the model does not have access to a tool to get the current date.

contents.question:
**Quality: Response Critique/Reasoning**

Rate the quality of response critique/reasoning
contents.explanation: These are accurate critiques and follow the assigned formats.

contents.question:
**Response Critique/Reasoning Feedback**

Write a few sentences of feedback to the contributor who last worked on this task. Try and be as actionable and specific as possible, this feedback will be directly surfaced to the relevant contributors!
